title: Headwinds gather against Boris' bid for Brexit deal
text:
He said if the plan was Britain's final offer, there would be no deal. "But I think it's also true to say that there is progression towards the space where we need to be."

'Almost impossible'

European Council President Donald Tusk was equally ambivalent. "Today I had two phone calls on Brexit, first with Dublin, then with London," he tweeted. "My message to Taoiseach [Irish PM] Leo Varadkar: We stand fully behind Ireland. My message to PM Boris Johnson: We remain open but still unconvinced."

Guy Verhofstadt, the European Parliament's lead Brexit spokesman, said it would be "almost impossible" to get the deal as it stood through the Strasbourg legislature, which has a role in approving it.

Speaking to his own Parliament, Mr Johnson declined to describe his offer as final, suggesting there was still room to negotiate. This steps back from previous Downing Street briefings to the media that the deal was "take it or leave it".

The question is how much derogation from his plan there can be before he starts to alienate his Brexiteer backbench and his crucial Northern Irish allies, the Democratic Unionist Party. At the moment, they are offering cautious support.

“We now glimpse the possibility of a tolerable deal,” leading eurosceptic Conservative MP Steve Baker told Mr Johnson during the parliamentary debate.

Advertisement

Mr Johnson said he'd had constructive telephone calls with European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker, German Chancellor Angela Merkel and Irish Prime Minister Leo Varadkar.

But time is short: in theory, the deal needs to be nailed down at an EU leaders' summit on October 17 and 18. On October 19, Mr Johnson is legally obliged – by a law MPs passed against his will last month – to seek a three-month delay to Brexit if a deal is not in prospect.

Mr Johnson told MPs that if the EU would not compromise as Britain had now done, the country would leave the bloc with no Brexit deal on October 31.

But speculation is growing that he might alternatively request the extension and then fight an election in which he blames the Brexit delay on opposition parties.

Two concerns

The European side has two main concerns with Mr Johnson's proposal. One is that by keeping Northern Ireland in Britain's customs territory, there will have to be customs inspections – and that might mean border posts, reopening old political wounds.

Mr Johnson insists it's possible to have a decentralised customs system that avoids this: "The proposals we are putting forward do not involve physical infrastructure at or near the border – or indeed at any other place," he said. But scepticism abounds.

The second issue is the plan to keep Northern Ireland in regulatory alignment with the EU. The Irish are worried about giving the Northern Irish Assembly – which has been suspended for more than three years after a political standoff between the province's two main parties – a periodic say over whether to continue aligning with the EU or switch to Britain. Again, this could keep the sectarian issues burning brightly.

Advertisement

"We cannot support any proposal that suggests one party, or indeed a minority, in Northern Ireland make the decisions for the majority. That would not be consistent with the Good Friday Agreement and it is not something we could possibly support as part of final deal," Mr Coveney said.

The EU reportedly has given Britain a week to amend its proposals. Some analysts suggest the bloc might try to run down the clock, forcing a Brexit delay that could lead to a second referendum.

Mr Corbyn, meanwhile, objects to the possibility that British and EU rules might diverge. Mrs May promised to maintain EU standards on workers' rights and the environment, but Mr Johnson appears to have dropped this.

“Deal or no deal, this government’s agenda is clear. They want a Trump-deal Brexit that would crash our economy and rip away the standards that put a floor under people’s rights at work, that protect our environment and protect our consumers," Mr Corbyn said.
description: EU leaders express doubt and opposition MPs display outright hostility, but the British PM says he wants to keep talking.
